review_title: Grateful for the experience, but leadership leaves a lot to be desired
pros: Culture is positive and encouraging Good benefits and PTO Pay is good Wonderful coworkers - I made many long term friends and memories here
cons: While the culture is positive, it also glosses over or downright omits wrongdoings 99% of the time. It runs over into toxic positivity as a result. This is an epidemic in Christian circles. We claim to be “in the world but not of the world,” yet we are no better at taking responsibility than anyone else. God is supposedly at the center of everything at CCU, but somehow no one ever seems convicted to own their failures or the ways they have let others down. CCU’s enrollment leadership excessively over hired during the height of the pandemic - concerning just about every enrollment counselor in the department at the time. Everyone’s concerns were realized in spring 2023 when CCU announced they were laying off 40% of the department. Leadership kept their jobs and took no accountability for the issue they created. Extremely disappointing and not at all Christ like.

review_title: Honestly...best place I have ever worked
pros: Working for CCU Online, we are able to work 100% remote as enrollment counselors. This is a sales position, which comes with its challenges, but leadership does a great job encouraging the team to operate with integrity and within a "sales as ministry" mindset. It is a delicate position to be in because they must bring in revenue to keep educating students but do not want to ever come across as pushy or manipulative and I believe that all of CAGS leadership does an excellent job communicating this (even if it is sometimes over-spiritualized). Even though the department is large, the teams are good-sized and everyone is very supportive. Training is thorough and you will receive a lot of support as soon as you start in your role. Prayer is encouraged and directors care about their team. The tuition benefit is great if you do not already have degrees. PTO is fair and being given the week between Christmas and New Year off without cutting into that makes it great. Benefits are fair as well.
cons: CAGS enrollment is one of the best paid departments and the starting pay has not been reevaluated since 2018. They would not have been able to grow the way they did if they had to keep hiring in Denver because the cost of living is just way too high for how much they start people out at. Since it is sales, it can have some stress and some individuals do steal leads from others, which does not seem to get addressed if they are one of the good enrollment counselors. Since the pay in other departments is very low, there is no opportunity to grow if you don't want to stay in a sales role. The other departments also suffer from a lot of turnover because they are paid so poorly.

pros: The hours are good and steady. You never run out of work, They give time away from work for worship, and have company wide worship. Good place to get experience at a University before moving on.
cons:
The University states that it is a Christian school. While this is true for the students, I don't feel that the company treats the employees with the same compass for the employees. The wages and benefits are low compared to other schools in the area for the same work, while the tuition rates are high for the students.

 There is a large amount of work for the employees that are there, and never enough employees to do all the work. The focus has shifted in the past year from retaining students to getting admissions up. Therefore all of the focus and new employees have shifted to admissions. 

There are no reviews and therefore no raises for good performance. There is only the hope of a yearly cost of living increase, which doesn't even cover the increasing cost of healthcare. Since there are no reviews bad employees can slip through the cracks and are only let go when they have done serious damage to the company.

Some of the students are so religious that they have a hard time differentiating between what's ok legally and what's ok within their religion (i.e. practicing conversion therapy)

The pay stinks. It's VERY low and the expectations are high.  For instance, a 5 week class pays $1500 but the classes may have 25 students and a 3 page paper due for each student weekly, along with discussion posts.  Do the math--you're spending at least 10 hours per week grading, assuming that you do the minimum and with the course prep time, etc that comes out to be about $15-20 per hour (about as much as a manager for a Starbucks).

There is also an expectation for faculty to go through a "course" each time you teach that walks you through the steps to be sure you're doing what you need to do in class.  I think that's great for the first couple times you teach, but EVERY time?  Seems excessive.
